comment.author: 7925034@N06
comment._content: As you can see the ghost has become so bored with this fellow, "it" actually becomes desperate looking for a way out. Looking, searching.  For a door, a window, a crack in the cealing. "It" pleads but of course no one can hear it's pain. Then "it"remembers it can vanish into thin air......so the problem resolved itself....true story.  The man later became a spirit himself.  After many years of being a spirit he retired. He now resides in Europe racing Formula one cars.

comment.author: 23581524@N03
comment._content: It is one of the traditional fraudulent Victorian spiritualist tricks, as one user said it is effectively a doll, he is holding it like a puppet; they would often be coated with a luminescent paint to give them an eerie glow - ectoplasm was produced by coating muslin in a similar. Great to see some photos of this

comment.author: 21109754@N02
comment._content: Look at the "spirit" in the other pictures in this photostream they are almost the same "spirit" Seems to me  that this is just a double exposure during the printing process. expose the paper with the negative of the man and then expose it lightly with the spirit image.  I don't know if this is the exact process that they would have been going through during this time period....but certainly seems like some sort of double exposure of some kind.

comment.author: 29428149@N08
comment._content: William Hope was a fraud, he indeed used pre-exposed glass plates to creat fake images of the dead. He was exposed several times, but somehow people kept believing in his work. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Hope_(paranormal_investigator)
